key_title: Key to the species of Blechnum

source.author: Entwisle, T.J.
source.title: Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta)
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Entwisle, T.J. (1994). Ferns and allied plants (Psilophyta, Lycopodiophyta, Polypodiophyta). In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Sori forming continuous band; pinnae finely serrate or entire
Sori discrete; pinnae with strongly curved teeth
Fertile and sterile fronds similar; lamina extending well beyond sori; pinnae attached by broad bases and not markedly reduced in size towards base
Fertile and sterile fronds markedly different; lamina hardly extending beyond sori
Fronds undivided, strap-like, or with few irregular, long lobes
Fronds regularly pinnate, with numerous pinnae
Sterile fronds with some pinnae shortly stalked or narrowed at base almost to midrib; adjacent pinnae usually separated along rachis
Sterile fronds with all pinnae attached by wide bases; most adjacent pinnae close-set, or contiguous
Lower pinnae shortly stalked, the remainder sessile; rachis with numerous scales and hairs; sterile fronds normally forming flattened rosette, fertile fronds erect
Most pinnae shortly stalked (only few near apex sessile); rachis bare or with scattered scales; sterile fronds generally erect
Lower pinnae greatly reduced and widely separated; frond texture variable
Lower pinnae not markedly shorter than upper pinnae; fronds harsh
Sterile fronds with pinnae less than 1 cm long, straight, apices blunt; rhizome creeping; fertile frond longer than sterile one and pinnae shorter and curved; alpine
Sterile fronds with pinnae more than 1 cm long, straight or curved, apices acute or rounded; rhizome short, fronds tufted
Sterile fronds with lower pinnae not reduced in length; lowermost pair curved and slightly deflexed
Sterile fronds with lower pinnae reduced and rounded, not deflexed
Stipe pale to brown; pinnae of sterile fronds falcate, tips toothed; fertile fronds flaccid with narrow, wiry pinnae
Stipe shiny, black; pinnae of sterile fronds linear, tips entire; fertile fronds erect with coarse pinnae
Pinnae sessile, bases flanged, except for an isolated pair of shortly stalked pinnae at base (which may be absent in some specimens); stipe and rachis rough, with black scales
Pinnae in lower part of lamina shortly stalked or with basal margins approaching midvein at least on upper side, separate
Pinnae stalked in lower half of lamina; fertile fronds longer and more erect than sterile ones; most mature sori usually confluent, laterally and/or across midvein of pinna

Pinnae stalked for less than lower one-third of lamina (pinnae bases in middle region of lamina may be narrowed (more so on upper side) but not stalked); fertile fronds similar to sterile ones or else (when growing among rocks) longer and with pinnae more separated; mature sori usually discrete, rarely laterally confluent, but never confluent across midvein of pinna
